Appearance
From Wiktionary, the free dictionary
See also: april, apríl, aprīl, and äpril

English

[edit]
English Wikipedia has an article on:
April
Wikipedia

Alternative forms

[edit]
  • Aprill (obsolete)

Etymology

[edit]

From Middle English apprile, Aprill, re-Latinised from Middle English aueril, from Old French avrill, from Latin Aprīlis (“of the month of the goddess Venus”), perhaps based on Etruscan 𐌀𐌐𐌓𐌖 (apru), from Ancient Greek Ἀφροδίτη (Aphrodítē, “Venus”). Displaced native Old English ēastermōnaþ (literally “Easter month”).

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • (UK) IPA(key): /ˈeɪ.pɹɪl/, /ˈeɪ.pɹəl/
  • (US) enPR: āʹprəl, IPA(key): /ˈeɪ.pɹəl/
  • Audio (US):(file)
  • (nonstandard, obsolete) IPA(key): /ˈeɪ.pɹaɪl/[1][2]
  • (Indic) IPA(key): /ˈep.rɪl/, (spelling pronunciation) /ˈaprɪl/, /-əl/; /əpˈrajl/
  • Hyphenation: A‧pril

Proper noun

[edit]

April (plural Aprils)

  2. The fourth month of the Gregorian calendar, following March and preceding May.
    Alternative forms: Apr, Apr., APR, 4
    Synonym: Eastermonth (religious or archaic)
    Holonyms: calendar year; year
    Comeronyms: January, February, March, May, June, July, August, September, October, November, December
    • 1845, Robert Browning, Home-Thoughts From Abroad:
      Oh, to be in England / Now that April’s there
    • 2019 March 18, Steven Pifer, Five years after Crimea’s illegal annexation, the issue is no closer to resolution‎[2], The Center for International Security and Cooperation:
      The little green men were clearly professional soldiers by their bearing, carried Russian weapons, and wore Russian combat fatigues, but they had no identifying insignia. Vladimir Putin originally denied they were Russian soldiers; that April, he confirmed they were.
    • 2020 May 12, Holly Yan, “Trump says the US leads the world in testing. But it’s far behind in testing per capita, studies show”, in CNN‎[3]:
      As of April 26, the US ranked 22nd in the number of tests performed per capita, according to the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD).
  3. A female given name transferred from the month name [in turn from English]; used since the early 20th century.
    • 1947, Hilda Laurence, Death of a Doll, page 27:
      I'm April Hooper. That sounds silly, the April part, but my mother was English and she always said there was nothing prettier than an English April.
  4. A surname.

Coordinate terms

[edit]
  • (given name): Avril

Derived terms

[edit]
  • Aprilesque
  • April-fish
  • April fool
  • April-gentleman
  • April-gowk
  • Aprilian
  • Aprilish
  • April Revolution
  • April showers
  • April showers bring May flowers
  • April Theses
  • April Uprising
  • Bloody April
  • days of April
  • mid-April

Descendants

[edit]

  • → Bengali: এপ্রিল (epril)
  • → Burmese: ဧပြီ (e-pri)
  • → Dari: اپریل (epril)
  • → Hausa: Afrilu

  • → Malay: April
  • → Maori: Āperire
  • → Marshallese: Eprōļ
  • → Tokelauan: Apelila
  • → Turkish: april

Cebuano

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From English April, from Middle English apprile, re-Latinized from aueril, from Old French avrill, from Latin Aprīlis (“of the month of the goddess Venus”), perhaps based on Etruscan 𐌀𐌐𐌓𐌖 (apru), from Ancient Greek Ἀφροδίτη (Aphrodítē, “Venus”).

Proper noun

[edit]

April

  1. a female given name from English

Anagrams

[edit]
  • Pilar

Ewe

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Borrowed from German April.

Proper noun

[edit]

April

  1. April
    Coordinate term: (native term) Afɔfiɛ

See also

[edit]
Gregorian calendar months: ɣletiwoedit
  • Dzove, Yanuar
  • Dzodze, Februar
  • Tedoxe, Mars
  • Afɔfiɛ, April
  • Damɛ, Mai
  • Masa, Yuni
  • Siamlɔm, Yuli
  • Dasiamime, August
  • Anyɔnyɔ, September
  • Kele, Ɔktober
  • Adeɛmekpɔxe, Nɔvember
  • Dzome, Dezember

German

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

    Inherited from Middle High German aberelle, from Old High German abrello, borrowed from Latin Aprīlis.

    Pronunciation

    [edit]
    • IPA(key): /aˈpʁɪl/
    • Audio:(file)
    • Audio (Germany (Berlin)):(file)

    Noun

    [edit]

    April m (strong, genitive April or Aprils, plural Aprile)

    1. April
      • 1741, Annales Cistercienses, Das ist, Cisterciensische, Oder Vielmehr Jährliche Kirchen-Geschichte Von Erbauung Cisterz, wie dieser Heil. Marianischen Orden seinen Anfang und Aufnahm genommen, und was sich von Anno Christi Geburth 1098. des Heil. Cistercienser-Ordens im ersten bis 1212. des bemeldten Ordens im 115. Jahr Denckwürdiges begaben, In V. Theil abgetheilet. In Lateinischer Sprache beschrieben Von dem Hochwürdigsten Angelo Manrique von Burgen [...] von dem Hochwürdigen Bonifacio Hiltprand [...] Ins Teutsche übersetzt; Endlichen Ans Tag-Licht und in Druck gegeben Von dem Hochwürdigen Wilhelmo II. [...] Dritter Theil, page 156:
        [...] hingegen hat ihn [= den Tag des seeligen Abschieds des Heil. Fastradi] Henriquez in sein Menologium auf den 21. Tag des Aprils gesetzet; [...]
        (please add an English translation of this quotation)
      • 1818, Eichenlaub, auf Luthers Grab gestreut, im Jahre 1817, von Dr. Johann Adolph Jacobi. Dritte Ausgabe. vermehrt, page 84:
        Am Dritten des Aprils trat der Kurfürst mit einer Begleitung, die seiner Würde entsprach, die Reise nach Augsburg an.
        (please add an English translation of this quotation)
      • 1834, Das Volks-Schulwesen in den Preußischen Staaten. Eine Zusammenstellung der Verordnungen, welche den Elementar-Unterricht der Jugend betreffen, von Dr. Johann Ferdinand Neigebaur, page 206 (from a "Dienstvorschrift für die Schulvorstände"):
        22) Bei Ueberreichung der Verzeichnisse der schulpflichtigen Kinder weiset der Vorstand den Lehrer an, mit dem Ersten Aprils und dem Ersten Octobers diejenigen aufzunehmen, welche dann das 8te Jahr vollendet haben.
        (please add an English translation of this quotation)

    Usage notes

    [edit]
    • Expressions like der erste April (der 1. April) are normally used to refer to a certain day of April and not to a certain entire month of April during a period of more than one year (e.g. der April des zweiten Jahres).

    Declension

    [edit]
    Declension of April [masculine, strong]
    singular plural
    indef. def. noun def. noun
    nominative ein der April die Aprile
    genitive eines des April, Aprils der Aprile
    dative einem dem April den Aprilen
    accusative einen den April die Aprile

    Coordinate terms

    [edit]
    Gregorian calendar months: Monate im gregorianischen Kalenderedit
    • Januar, (Austria, South Tyrol) Jänner
    • Februar, (Austria, dated) Feber
    • März
    • April
    • Mai
    • Juni, Juno
    • Juli, Julei
    • August
    • September
    • Oktober
    • November
    • Dezember

    Descendants

    [edit]
    • → Estonian: aprill
    • → Hunsrik: April
    • → Kashubian: aprël (dated)
    • → Slovincian: april

    Hunsrik

    [edit]

    Etymology

    [edit]

      Borrowed from German April.[1]

      Pronunciation

      [edit]
      • IPA(key): /aˈpriːl/, /aˈpril/
      • Rhymes: -iːl, -il
      • Syllabification: A‧pril

      Noun

      [edit]

      April m (plural April)

      1. April

      See also

      [edit]
      Gregorian calendar months: Monate im gregorianicher Kalenneredit
      • Januer
      • Februer
      • Merz
      • April
      • Maai
      • Juni
      • Juli
      • August ~ Aagust
      • September
      • Oktover
      • November
      • Dezember

      References

      [edit]
      1. ^ Boll, Piter Kehoma (2021), “April”, in Dicionário Hunsriqueano Riograndense–Português, 3rd edition (overall work in Portuguese), Ivoti: Riograndenser Hunsrickisch, page 13, column 2

      Indonesian

      [edit]
      Indonesian Wikipedia has an article on:
      April
      Wikipedia id

      Etymology

      [edit]

      From Dutch april, from Middle Dutch april, from Latin Aprīlis. Cognate with Afrikaans April, Malay April.

      Pronunciation

      [edit]
      • (Standard Indonesian) IPA(key): /ˈapril/ [ˈap̚.rɪl]
      • Rhymes: -april
      • Syllabification: Ap‧ril

      Proper noun

      [edit]

      April

      1. April

      Coordinate terms

      [edit]
      Gregorian calendar months: bulan-bulan kalender Gregoriusedit
      • Januari
      • Februari
      • Maret
      • April
      • Mei
      • Juni
      • Juli
      • Agustus
      • September
      • Oktober
      • November
      • Desember

      Further reading

      [edit]
      • “April”, in Kamus Besar Bahasa Indonesia [Great Dictionary of the Indonesian Language] (in Indonesian), Jakarta: Agency for Language Development and Cultivation – Ministry of Education, Culture, Research, and Technology of the Republic of Indonesia, 2016

      Limburgish

      [edit]

      Noun

      [edit]

      April m

      1. German-based and Veldeke spelling of april

      Malay

      [edit]

      Etymology

      [edit]

      Borrowed from English April, from Middle English apprile, from aueril, from Old French avrill, from Latin Aprīlis.

      Pronunciation

      [edit]
      • (English-based) IPA(key): [e.prəl]
        • Rhymes: -prəl, -əl
      • (Baku) IPA(key): [a.pril]
        • Rhymes: -pril, -il
      • Hyphenation: A‧pril

      Proper noun

      [edit]

      April (Jawi spelling اڤريل)

      1. April (fourth month of the Gregorian calendar)

      See also

      [edit]
      Gregorian calendar months: bulan-bulan takwim Gregoryedit
      • Januari
      • Februari
      • Mac, Maret
      • April
      • Mei
      • Jun
      • Julai
      • Ogos
      • September
      • Oktober
      • November
      • Disember

      Further reading

      [edit]
      • “April”, in Pusat Rujukan Persuratan Melayu [Malay Literary Reference Centre] (in Malay), Kuala Lumpur: Dewan Bahasa dan Pustaka, 2017

      Maltese

      [edit]

      Etymology

      [edit]

      Borrowed from Sicilian aprili.

      Pronunciation

      [edit]
      • IPA(key): /apˈriːl/
      • Audio (Gozo):(file)
      • Rhymes: -iːl

      Noun

      [edit]

      April m (plural Aprilijiet)

      1. April
        • 1949-1952, Anton Buttigieg, “Il-Bejta ta’ Dejjem”, in Qasba mar-Riħ, published 1977:
          Qalbi xebgħet bil-bejta
          li dejjem ta’ kull sena
          titwaqqa’ kull ħarifa,
          u kull April tinbena,
          (please add an English translation of this quotation)

      See also

      [edit]
      Gregorian calendar months: xhur tas-sena fil-kalendarju Gregorjanedit
      • Jannar
      • Frar
      • Marzu
      • April
      • Mejju
      • Ġunju
      • Lulju
      • Awwissu
      • Settembru
      • Ottubru
      • Novembru
      • Diċembru

      North Frisian

      [edit]

      Alternative forms

      [edit]
      • april (Föhr-Amrum, Mooring)

      Etymology

      [edit]

      Ultimately from Latin Aprīlis.

      Noun

      [edit]

      April m

      1. (Sylt) April
        Synonym: Gērsmuun

      Tagalog

      [edit]

      Etymology

      [edit]

      Borrowed from English April.

      Pronunciation

      [edit]
      • (Standard Tagalog) IPA(key): /ˈʔejpɾil/ [ˈʔeɪ̯.pɾɪl]
      • Rhymes: -ejpɾil
      • Syllabification: A‧pril

      Proper noun

      [edit]

      April (Baybayin spelling ᜁᜌ᜔ᜉ᜔ᜇᜒᜎ᜔)

      1. a female given name from English
